greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = Sum_{k=1 to d(n)} C(d(n)-1, k-1) d_k, where d(n) is the number of divisors of n and d_k is the k-th divisor of n.
link: Rémy Sigrist, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: a(p) = p+1, for p prime. - _Michel Marcus_, Sep 13 2014
example: Since the divisors of 12 are 1,2,3,4,6,12 and since row (d(12)-1) of Pascal's triangle is 1,5,10,10,5,1, a(12) = 1*1 + 5*2 + 10*3 + 10*4 + 5*6 + 1*12 = 123.
Also the lower vertex of the accumulation triangle of the divisors of n.
For instance a(39) = 88 because the lower vertex of ATD(39) = 88. ATD(39) is:
mathematica: f[n_] := Block[{d, l, k},d = Divisors[n];l = Length[d];Sum[ Binomial[l - 1, k - 1]*d[[k]], {k, l}]];Array[f, 100] (* _Ray Chandler_, Oct 31 2007 *)
program: (PARI) a(n) = {d = divisors(n); sum(i=1, #d, d[i]*binomial(#d-1, i-1));} \\ _Michel Marcus_, Sep 13 2014
print([A132065(n) for n in range(1,62)]) # _Peter Luschny_, May 18 2016
xref: Cf. A007318 (Pascal's triangle), A027750 (divisors of n).
results.author: _Leroy Quet_, Oct 30 2007
